title: Good Reasons to Go Slow on Abortion Precedents
sub_head: Overturning them all at once poses risks to legal and political stability. Gradualism is a better way.
body:
Should the Supreme Court eliminate all constitutional abortion rights? That question dominated oral argument in Dobbs v. Jackson Womenâ€™s Health Organization on Wednesday. Opponents of abortion have urged the court to overrule almost 50 years of precedents, including Roe v. Wade (1973) and Planned Parenthood v. Casey (1992).
Such a sweeping decision would be both precipitous and out of character. The justices typically move gradually before issuing disruptive decisions, and that approach is especially warranted in Dobbs.
